Maymin Assistant Professor Department of Finance and Risk Engineering Phone: (718) 260-3175 Email: philip.maymin@nyu.edu  Office: RH517C Links: http://philipmaymin.com    Social: Twitter LinkedIn  Profile  Biography Dr. Philip Z. Maymin is Assistant Professor of Finance and Risk Engineering at NYU-Polytechnic Institute. He is also the founding managing editor of Algorithmic Finance.   He holds a Ph.D. in Finance from the University of Chicago, a Master's in Applied Mathematics from Harvard University, and a Bachelor's in Computer Science from Harvard University. He also holds a J.D. and is an attorney-at-law admitted to practice in California.   He has been a portfolio manager at Long-Term Capital Management, Ellington Management Group, and his own hedge fund, Maymin Capital Management.   He has also been a policy scholar for a free market think tank, a Justice of the Peace, a Congressional candidate, and a columnist for the Fairfield County Weekly and LewRockwell.com. He is also an award-winning journalist and the author of Yankee Wake Up, Free Your Inner Yankee, and Yankee Go Home. He was a finalist for the 2010 Bastiat Prize for Online Journalism.   His popular writings have been published in dozens of media outlets ranging from Forbes to the New York Post to American Banker to regional newspapers, and his research has been profiled in dozens more, including The New York Times, USA Today, Financial Times, Boston Globe, NPR, BBC, Guardian (UK), CNBC, Newsweek Poland, Financial Times Deutschland, and others.   His research on behavioral and algorithmic finance has appeared in Quantitative Finance, North American Journal of Economics and Finance, Journal of Wealth Management, Journal of Applied Finance, and Risk and Decision Analysis, among others, and his textbook Financial Hacking was recently published by World Scientific. Jonathan Z. Friedman        Expected Date of Graduation: 2016        My research examines the ways that universities are enacting and responding to globalization, such as in efforts to educate students to be global-minded, strategies to compete on the international stage, and modes of (re-)organizing social scientific study of the world. I approach this subject using methods and frameworks from the fields of sociology and comparative education, with an interest in understanding the organizational and cultural dimensions of institutional change. For my dissertation, I am examining the ways in which globalization/internationalization has been enacted among eight case universities drawn from elite and mass tiers in the US and UK, focusing on the cultural meanings that university administrators attribute to these reforms, the rationales they offer in support of and against them, and variation in the institutional changes that have taken place.    Additional areas of research include participation in a long-term project housed at the U.S. Social Science Research Council investigating the way U.S. universities support the production and dissemination of knowledge about the world (titled, ‘ Producing Knowledge on World Regions ’). I also serve as Co-Investigator for a project studying the banal, global iconography of university websites and the digitization of study abroad marketing (with Prof. Cynthia Miller-Idriss, American University). At NYU, I have taught undergraduate courses for Steinhardt’s minor in Global and Urban Education Studies, and served as teaching assistant for various courses in the M.A. program in International Education.    Publications:    Friedman, J.Z. & Miller-Idriss, C. (forthcoming). “The Dual Logics of International Education in the Global University: The Case of Middle East Studies at NYU.” In S. Shami & C. Miller-Idriss (Eds.), Infrastructures of Knowledge: Middle East Studies for the New Millennium.    Friedman, J.Z. & Miller-Idriss, C. (in press, 2015). “The International Infrastructure of Area Studies Centers: Lessons for Current Practice from a Prior Wave of Internationalization.” Journal of Studies in International Education. Advance on-line article at: http://jsi.sagepub.com/content/early/2014/06/06/1028315314536992    Friedman, J.Z. & Miller-Idriss, C. (2014). “Gateways and Guest Homes: How Area Studies Centers Serve as Arbiters of Scholar Mobility.” In B. Streitwieser (Ed.), Internationalization of Higher Education and Global Mobility . Oxford: Symposium Books.    Reports, Evaluations and Book Reviews:    Miller-Idriss, C. & Friedman, J.Z. (2014 ). Evaluation of the Hagop Kevorkian Center for Near Eastern Studies, NYU. Grant Lewis, S., Friedman, J.Z. & Schoneboom, J. (2010). Accomplishments of the Partnership for Higher Education in Africa, 2000-2010. New York: New York University.
